title: What the Dual Ranking Exposed
headline_finding: The engine spent 8 cycles optimizing for transformation certainty while being blind to market accessibility. 28 of the top 50 transformation models are bottom-half in opportunity. Correlation between the two rankings is 0.088 — nearly orthogonal. The engine was systematically recommending fortress markets.

structural_blind_spots.evidence: Transformation Rank #1 (Retail Media, 86.5) is Opportunity Rank #413 (dead last). Amazon 77% share. Rank #2 (Warehouse Robotics) is O#406. The 5-axis system rewarded certainty without asking 'certainty for whom?'
structural_blind_spots.impact: The engine's top recommendations were structurally inaccessible. A user following the transformation ranking would target markets where incumbents have locked them out.
structural_blind_spots.fix_applied: CLA dual ranking. Transformation rank preserved (economy mapping) but Opportunity rank now sits alongside it.

structural_blind_spots.evidence: 18 defense models average 75.9 transformation, 48.2 opportunity — a 27.7-point gap, the largest of any sector. Security clearances, ITAR, procurement barriers, classified environments are structurally invisible to the 5-axis system.
structural_blind_spots.impact: Defense models scored artificially high because SN (structural necessity) doesn't distinguish 'will exist' from 'can be entered'. Palantir's dominance (V3-DEF-002, T#9 → O#412) was completely undetected.
structural_blind_spots.fix_applied: CLA MO axis captures concentration. Defense models now carry appropriate FORTIFIED/CONTESTED classifications.

structural_blind_spots.evidence: 10 of top-20 actionable models are acquire_and_modernize architecture. 75% of all A+M models are WIDE_OPEN. Manufacturing (NAICS 31-33) has 5 models in the actionable top 20. Yet the engine spent its deep dives on IT Services, Securities, Healthcare — tech-heavy sectors that score well on transformation but middling-to-poor on opportunity.
structural_blind_spots.impact: The most accessible, actionable opportunities in the economy — buying retiring businesses and upgrading with AI/cobots — were ranked in the 50-200 transformation range and never received deep analytical attention.
structural_blind_spots.fix_applied: Actionable top 20 (geometric mean) now prioritizes these models. v3-9 should deep-dive physical economy sectors.

structural_blind_spots.blind_spot: Category system didn't surface 'accessible but uncertain' models
structural_blind_spots.evidence: 29 PARKED models (composite < 60) have ACCESSIBLE or WIDE_OPEN opportunity. These were effectively dismissed by the engine. Examples: Specialty Textile Mill (T#364, O#86), AI Code Generation Tool (T#412, O#93).
structural_blind_spots.impact: Models in fragmented, wide-open markets with moderate transformation certainty were invisible. Some of these may be the most practical opportunities — lower conviction but wide open.
structural_blind_spots.fix_applied: Dual ranking exposes these. v3-9 should re-examine high-opportunity PARKED models.

structural_blind_spots.evidence: 0% of vertical_saas models (0 of 36) are WIDE_OPEN. The heuristic captures this but the 5-axis system didn't. SaaS markets are already crowded or quickly become so.
structural_blind_spots.impact: Multiple SaaS-architecture models scored 70-80 on transformation but are CONTESTED on opportunity. The engine overweighted their structural inevitability without pricing in competitive density.
structural_blind_spots.fix_applied: CLA correctly classifies most SaaS as ACCESSIBLE (viable but competitive) rather than WIDE_OPEN.

statistical_findings.interpretation: Nearly orthogonal — the two rankings capture genuinely independent information. This validates the dual system design.

engine_orientation_shift.before: Transformation-first: 'What will the economy become?' → ranked by certainty of transformation occurring
engine_orientation_shift.after: Dual lens: 'What will happen?' (transformation) AND 'Where can someone act?' (opportunity) → ranked by actionability (geometric mean)
engine_orientation_shift.implication: Deep dives should prioritize sectors with high ACTIONABILITY, not just high transformation certainty. The actionable top 20 should drive analytical resource allocation.
priority_sectors_for_v39: Manufacturing/Trades (NAICS 31-33, 23) — dominates actionable top 20, never deep-dived
Micro-Firm economics — #1 actionable model is an emerging category needing definition
Wholesale Trade (NAICS 42) — high opportunity, low transformation coverage
CLA refinement — more manual overrides for mid-tier models

for_v39: Agent B must produce competitive_landscape_assessment for every model card (not optional)
Deep dive selection criteria: weight actionability (T × O geometric mean) not just sector transformation phase
PARKED models with WIDE_OPEN/ACCESSIBLE opportunity should be flagged for re-examination, not dismissed
Defense models should be explicitly labeled FORTIFIED in one_liner when procurement barriers dominate
Manual CLA overrides should expand from 49 to 100+ models — prioritize mid-tier (T#50-150) where heuristics are least reliable
